primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Comparative Serological Study for the Prevalence of Anti-MERS Coronavirus Antibodies in High- and Low-Risk Groups in Qatar
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: In total, 4858 plasma samples were analyzed in this study. Samples were distributed as follows: 4719 plasma samples were collected from BD during previous studies [16–20] over a period of five years (2012-2016; age: 19-88 years; mean age 37 years), 135 plasma samples were collected from individuals that were in CC to four CP (age: 14-49 years; mean age 31 years), and four plasma samples were collected from CP (age: 30-70 years; mean age 52). The CC individuals represented the patient’s family members, healthcare workers, and camel farm coworkers. Samples from CC were collected within the first week of the patient’s admission to hospital. This study was approved by Qatar University-IRB Review Exemption No. QU-QU-IRB 622-E/16.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Genetic Evidence of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (MERS-Cov) and Widespread Seroprevalence among Camels in Kenya
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: The four camel breed types in Kenya sampled in this study were from historical and recent camel rearing tribes (Mburu et al.2003). Therefore, based on the geographical division of breed types, the 13 counties were grouped into five groups. For human sampling, high-risk groups such as camel herders and their immediate families were targeted. Sampling mainly focused on high-risk locations such as around watering points and common browsing locations that attract several herds of camels from different regions.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: MERS-CoV in Camels but Not Camel Handlers, Sudan, 2015 and 2017
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We collected samples from humans and animals at a live animal market, an outdoor slaughter area adjacent to that market, and the Tamboul Camel Research Centre (TCRC), all located in Tamboul, Sudan

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (MERS-CoV) RNA and Neutralising Antibodies in Milk Collected According to Local Customs from Dromedary Camels, Qatar, April 2014
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Dromedary camels in three barns at the Al Shahaniya barn complex and dromedary camels from a milking herd in the Dukhan area, Qatar

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Geographic distribution of MERS coronavirus among dromedary camels, Africa
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Netherlands Centre for Infectious Disease Control
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Dromedaries, 1 to 13 years of age, were collected as part of a study evaluating the presence of toxoplasmosis and respiratory tract diseases in 3 provinces (Afar, n = 118; Somalia, n = 11; and Oromia, n = 59) during 2011–2013

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Low-Level Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus among Camel Handlers, Kenya, 2019
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We enrolled participants on a rolling basis from 32 camel-owning households in Marsabit County, northern Kenya. We defined a camel handler as any person in the household who had contact with camels.
primaryEstimateInfo.symptomDefinition: Respiratory symptoms (fever, running nose, cough, nasal stuffiness, sore throat, chest pain)

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: MERS-CoV in Camels but Not Camel Handlers, Sudan, 2015 and 2017
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We collected samples from humans and animals at a live animal market, an outdoor slaughter area adjacent to that market, and the Tamboul Camel Research Centre (TCRC), all located in Tamboul, Sudan

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: MERS-CoV in Camels but Not Camel Handlers, Sudan, 2015 and 2017
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We collected samples from humans and animals at a live animal market, an outdoor slaughter area adjacent to that market, and the Tamboul Camel Research Centre (TCRC), all located in Tamboul, Sudan

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: High Prevalence of MERS-CoV Infection in Camel Workers in Saudi Arabia
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: The cohort for this study consisted of 30 CWs from Riyadh New Camel Market and 44 healthy controls recruited in Riyadh, KSA, and Iowa, USA. CWs were selected randomly, with the goal of including camel herders, handlers, and truck drivers. Camel herders feed, water, medicate, and milk camels. Camel handlers restrain, tighten (bind camels with ropes to prevent ambulation), and transport camels and have short but intense interactions with camels. Drivers help handlers and herders load camels into trucks. CWs control camels by placing their bare hands in the mouths of camels to avoid being bitten. Control samples of PBMCs were obtained from 14 anonymous donors at the University of Iowa and from 8 health care workers in KSA with no history of MERS exposure.
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: The ELISA for MERS-CoV S-specific antibody was read as positive (>1.1), negative (<0.8), or borderline (0.8 to 1.1).

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Cross-sectional study of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus in humans and dromedary camels in Diyala, Iraq
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Human subjects included 90 participants who were subdivided into 3 groups; 40 individuals had close contact with camels, 20 were normal healthy individuals, and 30 were individuals who had visited KSA for Hajj or Umrah.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: MERS-CoV in Camels but Not Camel Handlers, Sudan, 2015 and 2017
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We collected samples from humans and animals at a live animal market, an outdoor slaughter area adjacent to that market, and the Tamboul Camel Research Centre (TCRC), all located in Tamboul, Sudan

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: High proportion of MERS-CoV shedding dromedaries at slaughterhouse with a potential epidemiological link to human cases, Qatar 2014
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Camels that presented for slaughter in Doha, Qatar

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Cross-sectional study of MERS-CoV-specific RNA and antibodies in animals that have had contact with MERS patients in Saudi Arabia
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: This was part of a cooperative epidemiological response to the confirmed human cases of MERS with a history of animal contact. Notifications were issued by the Ministry of Health (MOH) associated with animals with a history of contact with MERS-patients

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Countrywide Survey for MERS-Coronavirus Antibodies in Dromedaries and Humans in Pakistan
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria:
Human serum samples were obtained from hospitals, primary health care centres and blood banks from people older than 15 years of age
Dromedary camels

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: High Prevalence of MERS-CoV Infection in Camel Workers in Saudi Arabia
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: The cohort for this study consisted of 30 CWs from Riyadh New Camel Market and 44 healthy controls recruited in Riyadh, KSA, and Iowa, USA. CWs were selected randomly, with the goal of including camel herders, handlers, and truck drivers. Camel herders feed, water, medicate, and milk camels. Camel handlers restrain, tighten (bind camels with ropes to prevent ambulation), and transport camels and have short but intense interactions with camels. Drivers help handlers and herders load camels into trucks. CWs control camels by placing their bare hands in the mouths of camels to avoid being bitten. Control samples of PBMCs were obtained from 14 anonymous donors at the University of Iowa and from 8 health care workers in KSA with no history of MERS exposure.
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: The ELISA for MERS-CoV S-specific antibody was read as positive (>1.1), negative (<0.8), or borderline (0.8 to 1.1).

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Seroprevalence of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Corona Virus in dromedaries and their traders in upper Egypt
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Camel traders in the southern part of Egypt involving Aswan, Asyut and New Valley

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Risk factors for serological evidence of MERS-CoV in camels, Kenya, 2016-2017
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Criteria for inclusion in this study were: counties with high camel densities, accessibility, security and interface areas for wildlife-livestock interactions.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Influenza is more common than Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (MERS-CoV) among hospitalized adult Saudi patients
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: The case definition of suspected MERS-CoV was an acute febrile respiratory illness (fever, cough, or dyspnea) with radiographic evidence of pneumonia. We collected data for all suspected patients.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: MERS Coronaviruses in Dromedary Camels, Egypt
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Persons working in the dromedary abattoirs

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Lack of middle east respiratory syndrome coronavirus transmission from infected camels
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Persons in close contact with an infected herd of ≈70 animals in Al Hasa, Saudi Arabia, during peak calving season

camelExposureLevelSubestimates.details: Community members not exposed to camels

Therefore, based on the geographical division of breed types, the 13 counties were grouped into five groups. For human sampling, high-risk groups such as camel herders and their immediate families were targeted. Sampling mainly focused on high-risk locations such as around watering points and common browsing locations that attract several herds of camels from different regions.
primaryEstimateInfo.socioeconomicStatus: 89% had no education; 7% had primary school level; 4% had secondary or more (Table S1).

primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Camels at the abattoir in Kano, Nigeria

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Cross-sectional survey and surveillance for influenza viruses and MERS-CoV among Egyptian pilgrims returning from Hajj during 2012-2015
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Egyptian Ministry of Health and Population
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: A cross-sectional survey was conducted at Cairo International Airport among Egyptians returning from Hajj during the week following the end of Hajj each year from 2012 to 2015 (Table 1). A team from the MOHP sought to enroll a convenience sample of approximately 10% of pilgrims from each flight returning from Hajj and congregating at the airport carousels, regardless of age, sex, and illness status.

primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Abattoir workers with and without occupational exposure to camels
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: A ≥ 90% reduction of signal was considered as evidence of neutralisation in the ppNT assay

primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Healthy dromedaries (Camelus dromedarius) >6 years of age in abattoirs

we tested blood samples from 100 camel handlers
and their families in the Cholistan desert in Punjab, Paki-
stan, a country with no reported human MERS (7).

samples with PRNT50>1:20 positive.
